explanation:
To determine whether OS_CreateSocketName violates the MISRA rule (no direct or indirect self-call) the analyser must inspect all functions/macros it calls to see if any call back to OS_CreateSocketName (directly or transitively).

- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: Called (via OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET) to obtain the socket record; its implementation must be checked to ensure it does not call OS_CreateSocketName (directly or via other callees).
- OS_SocketAddrToString_Impl: Called to render the address string; must be checked for any calls (direct or indirect) back to OS_CreateSocketName.
- OS_SocketAddrGetPort_Impl: Called to get the port; must be checked for calls back to OS_CreateSocketName.
- OS_strnlen: Called to compute lengths; include its implementation to rule out any unexpected callbacks to OS_CreateSocketName (transitive recursion).
- snprintf: Used to append port/parent name; include this symbol (or its wrapper) to ensure it does not (via user-provided replacement) call OS_CreateSocketName.
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET (macro/inline): The macro expansion may perform calls beyond a simple table access (e.g., calling OS_ObjectIndexFromToken or other helpers); include its definition to follow any calls originating from it.

Collecting these symbols (and their callee trees) lets the next analyser perform a complete reachable-call check from OS_CreateSocketName to verify there is no path that returns to OS_CreateSocketName (i.e., no indirect recursion).
